INRs and PT merely indicate a defect (innate or acquired) in particular aspects of the coagulation cascade, and could be due to a number of disease processes--neither would definitively establish the diagnosis of anticoagulant rodenticide ingestion. PIVKA is a more specific test for detection of anticoagulant toxicosis, but still cannot tell you which rodenticide might have been involved.
As for the comment about bromethalin, it is a rodenticide that affects oxidative phosphorylation (an essential part of cellular metabolism) and generally manifests as a central nervous system toxin; it is not an anticoagulant, so the clinical signs are quite different when compared to anticoagulant rodenticides.
Rat poison is a blood thinner, similar to coumadin. A simple blood test to check the INR or pt could have made the diagnosis.  The handler is my prime suspect.

The right to vote is mentioned five times in the Constitution.

The 15th Amendment says, "The right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of race, color, or previous condition of servitude."

It could be better, of course, but it's pretty clear. The modern difficulty involves nefarious efforts to deny or abridge the right to vote based on other attributes or characteristics that merely correlate with "race, color, or previous condition of servitude."

We do indeed need federal election standards, and making those rules universal would be easy: money.

Congress could write a uniform rulebook and impose it on all federal-impact elections (i.e., biennial Congressional and presidency), then offer the carrot of federal elections funds to all jurisdictions that adopt the federal rules in ALL elections, state and local.

If such a scheme were in place, few jurisdictions would decline the federal money just to run their own little renegade rules in off-year and local elections, and it would simplify the identification of discriminatory local rules by reference to the federal rules. If a local rule varies significantly from the federal rules, it should be presumed to have discriminatory intent and come under federal scrutiny.

As we have seen over the past decade, and especially over the past couple of years, voting rights are increasingly under attack as Republicans seek to create hurdles designed to reduce voting by Democratic-leaning voters. Expanding the geographic coverage of the Voting Rights Act would be an important and valuable step to help stop by these efforts. But two other things are needed to protect the vote.

First, we need to add the right to vote to our Constitution. The Constitution and Bill of Rights protect a lot of rights. But they don't officially guarantee a right to vote. Voting, however, is key to our democracy surviving and thriving and, therefore, such right should be guarantee in our nation's cornerstone document.

Second, we need federal election standards for federal elections. Because federal elections are currently run by state and local officials, it is quite easy to restrict voting through steps like putting far fewer voting booths in urban areas, using confusing ballots, not providing for a paper trail, and applying different standards for counting votes and for dealing with disputed votes. Such shenanigans can be reduced through establishment of uniform federal standards that include expand early voting in all jurisdictions. Doing so simply makes sense, as people throughout the US should have equal opportunities to vote and have their vote count.

I have seen too many conflicting studies on whether the type of sugar makes a difference to have a clear opinion.

What the introduction of HFCS has undoubtedly done, though, is change the economics of oversweetening foods. It is much cheaper and easier to make things sweeter, which is preferred for evolutionary reasons by a large majority of the population, than it is to find subtle seasoning and fllavoring changes that could have the same effect on overall demand. HFCS made it cheaper to make things sweeter, therefore, processed food got sweeter and profits went up. Tastes change in response to the available food, and sweeter food became the new norm. We became psychologically desensitized to sweetness levels, even as our cells became desensitized to normal insulin levels.

Economics explains the increase in obesity and diabetes, regardless of metabolic sensitivity to specific forms of sugar.
One clarification -- wood is primarily made out of lignin, which is not a carbohydrate.  Perhaps you are thinking of cellulose and hemicellulose, which are polymers containing glucose.

@G Love: My undergraduate degree is in biochemistry and my PhD. is in microbiology. I spent 10 years doing research in vaccine development, and I now teach Chemistry and Biology to high school students. I believe my familiarity with science is sufficient to comment on a secondary data survey. Besides, you've missed my point. I wasn't talking about the article, I was taking about Mark's response to the article. He went from "There is a correlation between the amount of added sugar available in a nation's food supply and diabetes" to "sugar is toxic", with no stops in between. This kind of irresponsible reaction opens the door for science deniers to seed doubts about the truth. He should have been more careful about his conclusions.

The data used in the study may not have been differentiated enough to determine the effects of different kinds of sugar supplements. However, the research is out there, and has been for many years. If Mark was following this issue he could have done some more research, and used this study as further proof of what science has been building towards for a decade or more; HFCS is a metabolic poison that should not be permitted in the food supply.

@HT: The concentration of lignin in wood varies with the hardness of the wood. It is a component, and often the primary one, of most plants. My intent was to point out that cellulose and hemicellulose are also polysaccharides, but I admit I wasn't expecting the author to recognize either chemical

Mark,

While the survey shows an impressive correlation, the authors don't go far enough in distinguishing between the effects of different kinds of sugars to justify your conclusion that "sugar" is toxic. Sugar, as the authors briefly mention but then completely ignore, is a common term referring to all of the saccharides. In effect, every carbohydrate (including wood) is a "sugar." If "sugar" causes diabetes, then shouldn't fruit, which is loaded with fructose, and beets, which are loaded with sucrose, cause diabetes? No evidence exists linking apples to obesity or diabetes. The study is too broad to be of any real use, as is the case with most surveys. However, better studies and experiments exist which point the finger at the real culprit; high-fructose corn syrup.

A quick look at the available data shows a shocking correlation. HFCS was introduced into most American soft-drinks in 1975-76. The obesity epidemic began in 1976. (USObesityRate1960-2004.gif) No other factor so clearly correlates to the onset of the obesity epidemic. Furthermore, recent experiments have demonstrated that HFCS isn't processed by your body in the the same way as sucrose (white or cane sugar). In fact, while HFCS has all of the calories of sucrose, your insulin system doesn't recognize it as sugar. You eat, but you don't feel full, leading you to eat even more while flooding your liver with sugar.

The FDA needs to put HFCS on the list of banned food additives, but it won't.
